18. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No never
we were always able to get enough to eat
and always able to cook it
Dear Mr. Smith,

I am writing to express my gratitude for your generous invitation to attend the upcoming dinner event. Your kindness is greatly appreciated, and I am honored to be included in such an esteemed gathering.

Please accept my sincerest thanks for your thoughtfulness.

Yours sincerely,

[Your Name]
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

On steam lined just plain good cooking over all fires and grills and less fat and not so good health.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

The other was a favorite to use as even kind of food is so expensive now. We had a half pound of salmon for 25¢ sugar $1.50 a hundred flour $.15 rolled $.25 salt $2.00 beef 53¢ a slice butter 60¢ more or less.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We used to be able to get dried beans in whatever quantities we wanted but now you don't see them and as for clothing it is now such a price that one can hardly get what one wants. Just an old pair of men's overalls one could get them for one dollar and a half now over $4.00 to $5.00 and the same with everything else.
We asked if we could get dried beans in whatever
you can get them. We want them for our own use
and as for anything else it is only much a nuisance
that we can hardly get what we want just now.

For one dollar and a half more over
£5.10 and the same with every story that
we have heard.
